Table.Industry / Model: IT Managed Service Providers and Cybersecurity
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): LOI fully signed in early Jan 2026 on a healthcare IT installs + MSP. Strong skill match, sticky MRR; seller will stay 3–5 years and help in transition.
Key match factors: Met seller; highly owner dependent today, but seller willing to stay 3–5 years
Hosted PBX recurring is about 25% of revenue (roughly $260k) near annual debt service
Plan to use working capital and possibly 20% equity injection to hire 1–3 near‑shore support in year 1
Broker is pushing a template APA; using 25 days to get full financials and weekly seller calls
Lenders: Jared at First Internet asked for a full file; Tom Lyons at Byline is interested and quoted Prime plus about 2%
Table.Risk flags: -1 owner dependence, churn and pricing pressure; project and bid dependence on installs

Table.Industry / Model: HVAC service and maintenance (commercial focus, Phoenix)
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): If AC is down, nothing matters. Needs-based, service contracts, route density.
Key match factors: License as moat with qualifier plan
Engineering degree counts toward 2 years of license experience; plan about 2 years of qualifier support

Table.Industry / Model: Light manufacturing with mandated replacement cycles (for example, traffic signs, safety gear)
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Compliance-driven replacement creates recurring demand. Simple operations with B2B revenue.
Table.Risk flags: -1 bid cycles, capex, and working capital swings

Table.Industry / Model: Niche B2B SaaS (reasonable multiple, sticky workflow)
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Exact skill set fit. Strong if churn low and pricing sane. Avoids paid-ads treadmill.

Table.Industry / Model: ABA/HCBS (Phoenix; Medicaid-heavy hybrid under LOI)
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Under LOI but heavily Medicaid exposed; the state moved to dismiss the Centria v. MercyCare case. Mission fit is high, but policy risk must shift to the seller note or he will walk.
Key match factors: About 75% HCBS and 25% ABA with roughly 96% Medicaid exposure; fee schedules and reimbursement history still pending
Pathward issued a term sheet; Live Oak sent a preliminary sheet; lenders want about $750k of seller note on full 10‑year standby
Plan to re‑trade terms with policy‑tied, forgivable note; end‑of‑January go/no‑go set
Seller slow on billing reports; will brief Live Oak and proceed only if structure protects DSCR
Table.Risk flags: -2 regulatory and payer risk; AZ Medicaid rate cut pressure; staffing and BCBA retention

Table.Industry / Model: Commercial landscaping maintenance
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Year-round Phoenix need. Contracted routes and crew ops suit process mindset.

Table.Industry / Model: Custom signs and banner printing (B2B)
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Repeat corporate orders and installs. Local moat and simple production.
Table.Risk flags: -1 project cyclicality, concentration, and working capital swings on AR and inventory

Table.Industry / Model: Daycare and preschool centers
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): He views this as a need and parents pay. Steady enrollment beats cycles.

Table.Industry / Model: Med spa injectables and selected laser services
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Injectables are sticky. Scottsdale demand is strong; cash pay helps.

Table.Industry / Model: Funeral home or mortuary transport
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Non-cyclical need with community moat. Predictable if well run.

Table.Industry / Model: Optometry and optical or hearing aid clinics
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Recurring exams, device sales, and renewals. Sticky patient base.

Table.Industry / Model: Plumbing service with maintenance plans (commercial)
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Mission critical. Maintenance agreements and cross-sell suit plan.

Table.Industry / Model: B2B logistics and moving or storage
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Accepts capex if contracts and utilization are strong. Route density matters.
Table.Risk flags: -1 capex, utilization, seasonality, and AR working capital float

Table.Industry / Model: Pet services (grooming, daycare, boarding)
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Owners see this as essential. Easy to package into memberships.

Table.Industry / Model: Automotive needs-based services (tires, inspections, repair)
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Clear need vs want. Adds fleet B2B options and route density.

Table.Industry / Model: Waste or junk removal and small roll-off
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Steady, simple operations. Can lock in B2B contracts and routes.

Table.Industry / Model: Pool service and repair (Phoenix)
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Year-round need in Phoenix. Contracted routes and repair upsell.

Table.Industry / Model: Elevator service and maintenance
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Code-driven recurring service and strong moat. High margin if staffed.

Table.Industry / Model: Roofing with inspections and maintenance subscriptions
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Recurring inspections and repairs with some project work. Drone inspections and claims know-how help.
Table.Risk flags: -1 weather cycles, labor, sales heavy; avoid new-build exposure

Table.Industry / Model: Home health and personal care (MSO friendly)
Table.Why it fits (1–2 lines): Healthcare mission plus aging market in Phoenix, but current AZ funding pressure and federal match changes raise risk.
Key match factors: Prefer diversified payers and clear DSCR
Table.Risk flags: -2 labor intensity and compliance; Medicaid reimbursement headwinds and budget pressure
